subject: Ethics
title: The Streisand Effect
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Streisand Effect.

hook.text: In 2003, Barbra Streisand sued to remove a photo of her mansion from the internet. Before the lawsuit: 6 views.

buildup.text: After news of the lawsuit spread, over 420,000 people viewed the photo in one month. Oops.

discovery.text: The Streisand Effect: trying to suppress information online often amplifies it far beyond its original reach.

twist.text: This creates a paradox for privacy rights. Requesting removal can turn obscure data into front-page news.

climax.text: The internet has a contrarian instinct. Tell it to forget something and it makes sure everyone remembers.

punchline.text: Trying to hide something online is the best way to make it famous.

quiz.question: What is the Streisand Effect?
options: When attempting to suppress info makes it spread more widely
A data encryption technique for celebrities
A privacy law named after Barbra Streisand
